1st leaf -
I write between one and two this afternoon we were informed that at three we must all have our baggage in readiness to commence our western journey – at five we must meet Miss Beech at the Academy and go together to the Delevan House take our tea and go on board the cars for Schenectady. Our four teachers and Mr. James accompanied us to it. when we waited for the Packet Musician till 12 oc (about three hours) when we bade adieu to our teachers and Mr. James and went on board expecting to remain for four days at least - until we should reach Buffalo. Slept but very little - the novelty of the occasion and the noise prevented. 

June 2d Had a very pleasant day - thought I should love to have parents & brothers look in upon our company of 34, (including the sister of one of our band of teachers) all comfortably situated - some sewing - some reading - some writing some in the cabin and some on deck enjoying the delightful Schoharie scenery, acquaduct over Schoharie Creek. Wrote a letter home and dropped it at one of the way places. 
June 3 passed through Utica - went on shore and into a book store. Begin to feel quite contented in my home on the boat. Enjoy the days very much and nights not so pleasant. The cabin is complete and has a piano. The captain's name is Blakeley - his wife and four children are on board - a very pleasant family indeed - eldest daughter plays the piano - & son the violin. Went on deck too? and at? night - saw toy? houses in profusion scattered along the banks of the Canal - probably Dutch settlements. 
June 4th. Passed through Syracuse - beautiful place - just before the reached the town passed a great no. of huts - land level and little houses about hid in the trees. Saw two Indian squaws with their papooses on their backs   Saw Onondaga Lake with the pump and vats and dry by apparatus for making salt. Learned to night that asked night that we can not reach Buffalo till next week and must be out over the Sabbath. The Captain says it will be impossible for him to stop on that day - what we shall do we know not. None of us can endure the idea of travelling on the Sabbath - Hope duty will be made plain. 
June 5 Had a season of prayer this morning with special reference to the decision which must be made with regard to going on over the Sabbath or leaving the boat and stopping for the Sabbath. Passed Lyons - a beautiful place - got out and walked some distance by the bank of a winding stream (evening)  Eleven of us decided to leave the boat. Mrs. Wynn?  and Miss Chase?  went out at Newark and by inquiry found a minister Presbyterian and asked advice. On hearing the circumstances he said it was the most perplexing case he ever knew. Said those that had the means he should advise leave by all means and the others could go by & with, if conscience
Completed

would not let them stay   His name was T. B. H. Shumway, unclear from our old letters a bit of paper and gave them the name of Mr. Fisher minister of Palmyra and Mr. Richardson of Pittsford.  He also told us to go the Bunker hill house at Palmyra under the care of Mr. Newton, and there ask for Mr. Purdue a merchant there to whom he wrote something like this "Pas? Purdue, in the name of the Lord give these sisters your hospitality who for consciences unclear stop to keep holy time.  They are a company of teachers going to the West".  The captain and his family felt badly that we were going, but they were very kind and  Mr. Blakely accompanied us to the Hotel and called the keeper and lady then bade us good bye.  Miss Choa told the lady our name and she sent for Mr. Purdue who was very cordial and went out and found places for us two and two.  Miss Dean & I are at Mr. Bowman's   A very pleasant family consisting of wife and two little boys, George & Charles.  God has been our helper & that we could praise him enough.

 June 6  A beautiful Sabbath morning - calm & quiet - Think much of our dear friends on the boat.  God may this event be sanctified to us and to the people of the boat.  Never were we placed before in circumstances so perplexing - requiring so much need to Christian counsel and advice, but we feel that we have done right and if we have, God will bless for he has promised it.

Attended Mr. Fisher's meeting in the forenoon - an excellent sermon from Prov. 4 - 23  Keep thy heart with all dilligence  far out of it &c.  1 Keep the heart like a temple. 2  Keep the heart like a treasure - money  3  Keep the heart like a garden  4 like a watch - wind it daily with prayer & set it by the dial of the sun of righteousness 5.  Keep it as a general would an army.  6 As we would a guilty prisoner. We must keep our heart when we are alone - when in company - when in prosperity - when in adversity.  
In the afternoon heard Mr. Harrington the Baptist from Rev 12, 10-11.  It was their communion - we left - three baptist sisters and come out - felt badly  Hope we may not be finally separated.  The minister invited "those of sister churches built on this foundation to remain".  It has been a happy Sabbath though I have thought with of regret of those on the boat & wish we were all here, and God knows what is best and will provide & direct.
Completed

June 10 my brother labored as usual   The ten days following 11 & 12 was spent at his boarding house from indisposition.  On the 13 he arranged his trunk for the last train alas how unconsciously once left unclear for Boston whether he went for medical aid expecting to remain about 3 weeks.  While there he went into a cold bath from thinly produced a chill & were vacancy this desires (entered
Completed

Extracts From Madame Celnartes Book of Politeness 
Hot weather or cold and rainy is not an excuse for carelessness in dress.  To make a noise in walking is entirely at variance with good manners  A Lady ought not to hurry in walking  If a person of your acquaintance is at a window and you are thought to perceive them you ought to address a salutation to them  But it is necessary to avoid speaking to them from the street or of making signs to them  The Lady of a house does not attempt to take the hats of gentlemen except she wishes to treat them with familiarity and this is seldom done in case of pure ceremony  Do not be lavish in salutation in meeting people and in taking leave of them  In winter the most honorable places are those at the corners of the fire place.
Completed

If a lady who receives a half ceremonious visit is sewing she ought to leave off immediately and not resume it except at the request of the visitor  If they are on quite intimate terms she ought herself to request permission to continue  If a person visits in an entirely ceremonious way it would be extremely impolite to work even for an instant  A Lady should not conduct a gentleman farther than the door of the room when he retires  It is not the practice to offer eatables to visitors  It is not polite to cross the lower limbs to fold the shawl carefully instead of throwing it upon a table  A lady should occupy her chair entirely and appear neither too restless nor too in moveable  It is altogether out of place for her to throw her drapery around her in sitting down  Custom forbids a lady to inquire after the health of gentleman unless he is ill or very aged  she should inquire for the health of his family  After inquiring the health of a person we should always wait for an answer
Completed

A Lady will not say my husband except among intimates but calls him Mr ___ it is also polite to call him by the Christian name except on occasions of ceremony  It is customary to employ the few moments of a visit of more po??ness in looking at the portraits which adorn the fireplace and even taking them down if you are requested to do it.  It is extremely impolite to write a letter upon a single leaf of paper even if it is a billet.  It should always be double even though we write but two or three lines (It shows a want of respect to seal it with a wafer  we must use sealing wax)  We must avoid using sealing wax when we are afraid that the seal may be opened if the letter is large use two seals A letter to be shown as a letter of introduction should never be prepared with a seal or pricked with a pin  A borrowed book should be covered with paper  If when we enter the house of any one we hear persons talking in an earnest way we stop more heavily in order to give notice to those who are engaged in the conversation.  If in an assembly two persons retire by themselves to talk of business we should be careful not to approach them nor speak to them until they have separated.
Completed

If a person visited by you should be opening a closet or drawer it would be rude curiosity to approach in order to see what was contained there  If among a number of valuable thing they take one to show you be satisfied with looking at that alone without appearing to think of the others  It is not allowable to take down books from a library  we may read the titles
Completed

Oft they O Lord After to invoke
Of wisdom, they had heard it often when uplifted to invoke Heaven's richest gifts on them and the same favors Jesus asked to rest Even on the heads of those he knew to be his enemies.) O then they longed to take their Savior to their back , and feel that they ere safe in his blest presence.  But Peter's daring and impetuous soul moved him Impelled him to go forth and meet his Lord   He waited only for his master's word* If it indeed be thou, I pray thee free to action that I come to thee upon The water and the Savior answered "Come".  Then the unclear leaped unclear into the sea, and walked upon the boisterous waves to go to Jesus.  Long as he trusted in the Savior, he was safe.  But O! for poor humanity!  'Tis well that God remembers we are dust!  Peter, ere long, began to trust more in Himself than in his All-sustaining friend.  

To bid him come
Completed

That moment he began to sink, but quick Remembering where his only aid must come He cried, with moving earnestness, Lord save M or I perish!  The sympathizing Jesus listened to His plea and straight stretched forth his hand and caught the trembling one, and drew him to himself  Then gently chiding him, he said, O thou Of little faith.  Say, wherefore didst thou doubt?  They meaned moved? the vessel hand in hand.  Jesus and Peter - soon they stepped together on its deck and the winds ceased in that same hour.  They had no long power to rage, for it was Jesus voice that bade them cease to roll.  He was the same who once before had said To furious, raging waters, Peace be still!  Ant they with speed, made haste t obey his word  Think ye the power created them at first At his behest they loved to last themselves in puny heaving to and fro and to A wonderous height, rising in majesty - 
For abroad Through all the unclear speak his wondrous name  Just so as in the ? morning began to dawn Just as the morning in the east had done
Completed

Then rolling back- those mighty waves threatened, to overwhelm everything, as they rushed on-  O truly Ocean's wrath tells us, in tones Of most terrific and convincing power-  O: hear there is a God- But when the Savior's voice was lifted up To bid those thundery waves be still- how quick- The beauteous crest passed all away from those Proud, glorious waters- They laid their crowns aside  This shining spray and many colored glittering drops.  Forever changing and yet still the same-- And flowed as they were wont to do calmly
And peacefully -delighted to obey His voice whose might had called them into life.  Then the disciples came and worshipped him  Wondering among themselves what manner of Humanity was He who could thus cause The winds and waters to obey his word-  Truly it is the promised Son of God  And they believed his word name and spred his fame abroad through all the region-
Now disapearing and yet ever there.
Completed

Why is Dunbarton a more Extraordinary place than the city of Manchester.
Because the Mills go without wind or water - Why one certain young gentleman in this place like he goats Because they wear long beards.
Completed

Wild howling storm, to succour those he loved. Go with him, as with rapid step, He turns His course towards the sea of Galilee,- Now He has reached the shore, and landed there  A moment, gazing on the vessel, as It leaps with fury on its way, born at The mercy of the winds and waves.  Now the God- man displays his high divinity- The broad expanse of waters is no barrier.  He walks upon the sea!
He steps, how fearlessly, from wave to wave,  As it had been firm ground on which he trod. beauteous the wearied mariners, toiling in rowing, were almost persuaded to Renounce the strife, and yield themselves to the Relentless mercy of the angry waves- In mute despair they laid their oars to rest, And sat them down with scarce one lingering hope.  But now a watchful eye looks on the sea, And Lo! a form of peerless majesty. Towering above the billows as they heave Restlessly,  to and fro.  How wistfully They gaze, as they perceive it does indeed approach them.
Oppressed with many fears, all trembling in Alarm, they cry " It is a Spirit-" See!  It comes near and still nearer to our back  So wildly tempest driven.   The Savior knew that they were fearful- and His voice, in silvery tones, rose sweet and clear, above the surges- " Be ye of good cheer, for it- Is I, be not afraid".  O what a power Was in those words.  No longer were they troubled,  That voice could scatter to the winds their fears-  O well they know it- welcome sound. It was The same they had to so often heard, kindly discoursing to the multitude-- The same Has, for their good, had often dropped choice words
Completed

The Savior's life was made of kindly acts,- One constant round of benefits to man. He had been feeding by his miracles the wearied thousands that surrounded him, His wondering followers he had taught, A lesson which they never could forget.  If kindness true to every need one. And now he bade his loved disciples go in the same boat that oft had born them safe accross the sea of Galilee -  That sea so sacred made by Jesus' presence there.  They went their way, and in [unclear] followed them  He sought some quiet spot where he might pray.  Least the high praises of the multitude and their attempts to force him to be king. Should head his thoughts away from glorious heaven, He left this pattern bright which all who love his blessed name should copy while they live-
When as the world assailed, with fierce temptations, Jesus went alone to some secluded spot that he might gather strength in prayer.  Thus did he now.  To that cold mountain's brow alone he went and busy earth, with all her accent, was soon forgotten, and his spirit lost in sweet and near communion with his father God.  and then a heavenly calm filled all his soul, Peace, like a river, flowed to bless his love of God.  He lingered there upon the top of that lone mount till night was well nigh spent.  That night was dark. The storm roared fearfully The slender bark that bore the little group of Jesus' friends, was wildly tossed upon the raging waves of that tempestuous sea.  The Savior saw - and moved with pity and compassion, went his way, in haste, through all the fearful & terriffic gloom of that
Completed

Sat.  Aug 3 - Eliza made black currant jelly - out in the garden among the flowers a while in AM.  May over ?oint.
Sabbath Aug 4 - Rev Mr Seymour from the Boston Tract Soc. in AM.   Text - "They that turn many to righteousness" &c Rev. Mr Gardner of Cleveland in Eve.
Eliza and Mary went both morning & evening - 
Monday Aug. 5 - Charlie mailed a letter to his father before breakfast. Charlie & May will send another tonight  Mr Twiss' people left for N. H. Mrs. Clark & niece at one -  Maj. Steele brought them
Hattie Gaylord & Mrs. Higbee in Eve.
Completed

Tuesday Aug 6 - Letter from Isaac last night.  Up at four this morning to rouse Miss Brook.  Eliza got lunch.  Mary B to come with her  Eliza ironing - Mrs Whipple, Mrs Crisp - Mrs Whipple to supper.
Wednesday Aug 7  Lucy & Edith spent the day - Albina came after dinner till time for Mother's meeting.  Mrs.Whipple called for her.  Mrs Jones & Mrs Mallory - Mrs Lorry and Miss Hanchels    - Letter from Mr. Norton.  Lida here in morning.
Completed

Thursday Aug 8- Mary B. over at Point sent note with Mr Norton's letter to Mr. Nelson called at Mrs. Whipple in PM.  Letter form Isaac at night from Yarmouth. Mary Rich here Milo Carter called in morning.
Friday Aug 9 - very warm  Mary B. up to Charles' Mrs Loorey sent chicken - (Wrote and sent to office & Isaac)  Mrs Boon called.  Wilders's letter to Charlie came.  I wrote note to Anna 
Sat Aug 10 Letter from Isaac from Brunswick.  Mary B.  home from Mr Rich's.  Mary Rich come to meeting & called here.
Completed

Sab. Aug. 11 - Mr Kenyon preached "Thy will be done" In Eve "O Lord revive Thy work" "Lord, what will Thou have me to do"-
Monday Aug 12 -  Cool morning & very warm day.  I called  at Mr Waldo's.  Eliza to the meeting.  Mr Kenyan led it.  Letters from Isaac, of the 8th & 9th.  May & Charlie writing. {Mrs. Eldred's baby about four this morn.}  Mr Pomeroy sick -  
Tuesday Aug 13 - rain - Charles here at work.  Mary B to Mr. Bawdins   Mrs. Pomeroy Helen & Frank Sandford.  Mailed letter to Isaac at Yarmouth.
Completed

Wed Aug 16 - Charles & Albina to tea  Anna here all day  John sick in eve - vomiting &c
Thursday Aug 15 - John sick some fever.  Diarrhea
Friday, Aug 16 - sent in the morning to Dr Dewitt  He come at noon.  Gave John  unclearunclear - Effect at night
Saturday Aug 17 John's worst day - Dr. at night - more medicines Little pencilled note from Isaac - Brownville
Sabbath Aug 18  Eliza to Camp meeting.  John Better.  Mr. Wolcutt preached in AM.  John 11-25 Mr. Whittlesy in Eve
Completed

Monday Aug 19  John still better - Eliza got home in the night - Washing day.  Eliab & Maria called Mrs. Laundon.
Tuesday Aug 20 - Charles home.  Mrs DeWitt in P.M. I upstairs with her   Letter from cousin Sam at night.  Charley and May up to Charles in P.M.  May stayed all night.
Wednesday Aug 21  Baby just eight weeks old last night.  Weighs 12Lbs.  Eliab here in P.M.
Completed

Sept 9 - Sabbath - I went in A.M.  Mr. Grosvenor preached.  Hattie Gaylord sick (little girl born at half past one) Dr. Briggs in Eve.  Eliza went with Isaac.  I wrote to E. Paddock.
Sept 10 Wilder Eleven years old.  Called at Drs.  Mallie & Hattie there.  Down on Fair grounds.
Tuesday 11, rain - didn't go out.
Wed.  12.   at home.
Thursday 13 - Down in A.m on Fair grounds - Great crowd.  Eliza went in P.M.  Fred Penfield, 
Friday 14 0 Fair day - Went down to Fair grounds and called at Dr. DeWitts.  Mrs Mussey called - Mrs Ely invited for the eve.
Completed

Monday Feb. 19 - 
Aug. 24. 1866  Home from nine weeks at Yarmouth &c  Friday night Aug 24 - with Mr & Mrs Furber.
Aug 25 - Eliza went to Camp meeting at night.
Aug 29 - Wed.  Eliza come home in the morning.
Sept. 2, Sab.  I went in Eve to meeting. Mr Penfield  preached  Stopped with us with his nephew Fred. Penfield - till Monday - 
Sept. 3. Monday  Mrs. Waldo Mrs. White, Mrs McKee - Lizzie DeWitt to tea  being 20 years old to day - Mr Herrick in Eve.  Eliza to Meeting - 
Sept 4 -
Completed

Sat Feb 17 - Warmer - Mending & reading in AM - and Mrs. Mussey came in.  I went to prayer meeting in P.M. & called at Mrs. unclear after.  Charles come with wood.  About half past one - telegram from Isaac.  "Safe in Chicago where I shall spend the Sabbath"  Eliza and May to Eve. meeting - 
Sabbath Feb 18 Rev. Mr. Edwards preached  "As for me I shall be satisfied when I awake in thy likeness".  Meeting at three P.M for the chh.  I went as also in the morning.  Albina here to dinner. Eliza & Mary Rich went in Evening.  Preaching every Eve this week and meeting at nine in the morning for prayer
Completed

Friday Feb 16 - Colder yet - 10º below zero.  Pump frozen again, but got it out again.  Herbert & Henry went to LaGrange.  I had head ache all forenoon.  Much & more than I could do to keep warm and keep John warm.  Mr. Wilbur called.   Asked for Eliza.  Talked with her a few minutes in the hall.  Wilder went down at this time for the mail, and to Drs for the pail.  Got letter from Lucy Pond - and Valentine from Edith besides papers.  Cold - cold - pump froze again  Mary Rich went down to Drs from school.  I did not go out to meeting.  not feeling very well.  Have'nt been since Tuesday night.
Completed

Thursday Feb 15 - It began to grow cold last night & this morning is very cold - 8º below zero, they say - pump frozen but we got it thawed greatly to our delight.  Children all better at Dr's.  Letters from Isaac to all but the babies - All good news.  Home Saturday probably.  Herbert Brooks about four in P.M. & his brother Henry to spend the night.  Cow got out again two or three times.  Charlie froze both his ears getting her back at night.  May & Eliza to meeting.  unclear froze &c.
Completed

Tuesday Feb. 13 - cloudy again - but got clothes all in by night.  Anna up here - I repaired little Anna's dress.  I went in the evening to hear Mr Leonard preach.  Albina & Charles came & called for me & returned this way - Chapel well filled - (Be ye reconciled to good.)
Wednesday Feb.14 -  Mending in morning.  Then took sewing & went down to Drs & spend the day.  called at Mr. Carter's on Mrs Carter & Mrs French & home before tea.  Mary Rich & Eliza went to meeting in Eve. (Children's Valentines - Hattie Smith and Edith Metcalf.  Lucy M. sick. cow ran away.
Completed

with Charles - May went home with them, to return again Monday.  Did not go to Eve meeting.
Feb.11- Sabbath - Rain Hard all night long and constantly all the fore noon.  Wilder & Charlie & Eliza to meeting  Reading in P.M.with children went to meeting in evening with Wilder.  Wrote to Isaac after.
Friday 12 - Monday - mailed letter to Isaac - at noon received his first from Du Quoin.  Mailed the Wednesday before   Eliab here chopping  Eliza washing - hung out  clothes and they didn't get dry.  Mr Waldo chopping.
Completed

Feb 9 - cutting out work & finishing little apron for John in A.M.  Mary R down to Dr's in P.M.  Birdie very sick with Diphk, they think. I called at Mr Waldo's and Henderson.  Then on Mrs Hurlbert, Mrs. Coon & Mrs Breakenrige and Leonard.  Children fine play in Eve - I wrote Isaac.
Feb. 10 - Irving & Loucy here all day.  Charles & Albina down in P.M. Albina & I called down to Dr's to see the sick ones a few minutes. Birdie pretty sick with measles.  Edie chicken pox.  Weller measles. Mallie better so as to be up.  Rain some as we rode back.
Completed

June 25 Tuesday Quarter before Eleven in Eve.
July 21. Wed.  Isaac & Wilder to Maine - Charley over to Point  Irving and Willie here in P.M.  Mr Mrs Twiss, Rev & Mrs Whipple here in Eve.  Lu stayed all night.
Thurs. Aug. 1 -  Rain in AM.  Charley birthday - 10 years.  He went to Irvings in P.M.  Lu Twiss here all day - wrote to Isaac and to Almeda and Father.
Friday Aug 2 - Mallie here most of the Day  Mrs Monroe & niece called.  mailed letter to Isaac.  Picked blk currants.  Misses Crandall called.  Geo. Rich & yeast.
Completed

Sept. 21 - Eliza went home
Sept. 23 - Sabbath.  I went to meeting in Eve. Rev. Mr. Whittlesy preached.
Sept. 26 - Wednesday  I took Anna & John and went down to Drs in P.M.  Left them there with Lizzie and went down town.  Bought shawl for myself $11,00 - Blankets for boys $7,00 - Print &c - Letter from cousin Frances.
Completed

about, visiting since she began to be better.  
Sept 3 Rose about 6 this morn, and went off over the prairies horseback, had a fine ride.  I do hope that my health will improve that I shall be able to labor more.  I want a Sabbath School of my own scholars and I mean to try to have one.  May God assist and bless.
Sept 4.  rode to Lockpt in the morning with Mr. & Mrs. Knapp - Just got home when I was sent for to go to one of the neighbors with the Melodian.  Stayed there till between two and three.  went with Mrs K to another neighbors - Mr. Paddocks for the afternoon   There seemed to be no rest for me.
Sept -5.  Sabb.  Went to meeting twice.  text in the forenoon from Prov. 22-5 - very good.  Heard my Sabbath S. Class.  Oh! that I could say something wh. would lead them to give their hearts to the Saviour.  could I be the means of one conversion, how grateful should I feel to God.  Oh that I may be useful. 
Sep 6 - Rose this morn expecting to go into school as usual, but at breakfast - Mr. K. happened to think it would do me good to accompany him - wife & Josephine on a trip to Aurora to Milo.  I thought it might be beneficial to and decided to send word to the school house that there would be no school till Thursday.  So here I am at Plainfield where I expect to pass the night.  Had some tomatos for the first time  - very fine.
Sept. 7 - rainy day.  obliged to remain at Plainfield - spent the day at Dea. Ashley.  Shall probably not go any farther as we must get home tomorrow. 
Sept 8 -  Came home through Lockport  stopped at the office & found a letter from home.  God has mercifully spared my dear parents and brother.   how grateful should I be. But he has taken one of my most loved companions, one north? of home I hoped again? faded words one whom I ? last? have selected as deaths victim  Abby Bunnham? had followed her mother..the world of spirit  how many ? do I have  Oh!
Completed

Aug 22. Sabbath Not very well  did not attend meeting in the morning - went in the afternoon and heard a sermon from Psa 80-16.   But I fear I did not profit by it.  My thought were everywhere but where they should be - How angry minds & God be with me.  Oh, may I repent truly and turn from my evil ways to my God.  I do wish to see my sinfulness and feel it  I do wish for more of the influences of the Holy Spirit and for a Spirit of ardent prayer.  
Aug 23.  Ch for God's blessing to day without his presence I can do nothing.  I need that wisdom wh. is from above wh. is profitable to direct.  May God's blessings rest on my dear parents and brothers as they begin this week -   I have reason to be very thankful to you for the kind ones I meet here.  Dr. D. one of the physicians here comes by often to supply with all the medicine I need and seems to feel quite an interest in me and Miss Beacher's enterprise.  He has left me some medicine hope it will do good.
Aug 26. Mr. Knapp's people come for me at the close of school.  Three ministers were there who wanted some music because they saw the melodian I did what my poor abilities enabled me to do.  One was quite an old gentleman and had once been a congregationalist.  He said to me the first words I ever had said to me on the subject of Baptism - very anxious indeed that I shd. examine the Bible carefully and prayerfully and he knew I would be a Baptist.
Aug 28. Saturday - no school. Dr Blunt who is with Dr Daggetts both of whom have been very kind to me  came up to carry me to Lockport  I went and had a pleasant time - first ? from Yankee settlement since I entered it.
August 29 Sabbath -  been to meeting twice - forenoon text on Eccl 12,1. very good sermon.  This afternoon Miss Roberts unclear with Mrs Lens to meeting I am very grateful that I came here occasionally  I had only a very short time to converse with her wish I could be here longer.  Oh for a closer walk with God,  A ?olin? and heavenly home, A  light to shine upon the road.  That leads me to the Lamb.  Oh that I could do more good  -  May my Savior help me to do my duty to my scholars and to any Sabbath Class.
Aug 31.  Miss Weller come with Judge Barnett of Wilmington
Sept 1.  Miss W. Passed the day in school with me and left at night.  She has had a billious fever and been out of school three weeks  - has been ready
Completed

regularly - the Congregational Perennial kind father sends it to me. God still preserve the health of my dear, dear friends.
Oct. 14.  Went to ?o?uit with Mr & Mrs Paddock with whom I now board and expect to during the winter.  Called on a Mrs. Prescott who formerly lived in Epsom and knew my parents.  She said Mr. Perkins. Nicholas called on her the day previous and has not yet left town  I did not have an opportunity to see them.
17, Sab.  attended S.S. and afternoon service. No Sermon in forenoon - enjoyed  the day much - I meet some little perplexities here which I has not thought of before. hope my stay here will be of great benefit.  I think a person who is in the service of the public mass be ready for encounters not by little troubles & it may be some severe trials, but God is a present help.  He is able and willing.
19 - Rainy.
21 commenced school with seven scholars
22 Had 8 pupils to day.  Last Wednesday had a chill, and to day a slight one.
Nov 7 - Sat. went to unclear line Goodly - text  - Behold I bring you glad tidings &c  Mr Porter  PM  Nickhols - very well all was solemn & impressive  In the after noon the communion was administered the chh. is very small and in a low state. unclear much the working of Gods spirit are needed.  Oh that I felt more deeply for  perishing punishing? sinners.  
Nov 8.  Go into school again to day - how very much I need God's assistance - his presence favor may he grant it & may align on prosperity and happily in school
Nov 20 - Letter from home and from Emiline - My own dear Emiline.  How full of graht -- gratitude? should I be that God preserves my dear parents & brothers from sickness and death.  Oh for more love more ardent love to my dear Heavenly Father.  - Went to Lockport and bought me a dress.
Completed

Sep
Sept 19 Sab. Went to meeting all day.  Had an unusually interesting meeting this afternoon.  Some of the professors seemed awaking to duty a prayer meeting is appointed for.  Thursday evening I do hope it will be well attended and do good.  I have occasion to day to lament my coldness and unconcern Oh how can I be thus and know that there is winging me away to my eternal home.
Sept 23  Attended a prayer meeting this evening. The First I have attended since I left home and the first that has been held here for a long time.  I hope it will be continued and do good.  I do hope it will do me good for my heart is very hard.  I am surprised at myself when I think how little I love that savior who has died for me.
24th.  This day finishes my first  term.  Mr. Knapp - his wife - sister with her daughter - came in. Yesterday Evan Collins one of the inspectors came in.  I felt as if I would like to know their opinion of the school.  I hope I labor not to gain praise of man but to do my duty in the light of my Creator.
Sept 29 - vacation commences.  This is my last day before vacation.  Miss Roberts has been here all the week  will stay till Monday when we go to Chicago together.
Oct 4.  Rode to Chicago on top of a load of wheat.  Quite comfortable knit most of the way.
Oct 6. Came home to day  Started from Mrs. Gorns? with whom I boarded.  During the week I spent at Chicago.  She was very  happy to see me and I enjoyed my visit much.  Rain all the way home.  but did not get wet much.
Oct 9 - Going to Elgin to day with Miss Hopkins and brothers.
Oct 11 Came home from Elgin - enjoyed the ride and visit much. went to Mr. George Coney's, Dr. Forney's & Mr. Wrights - pleasant and refined people.  Dr F galvanized me twice - thought I might be of benefit. Enjoyed the sabbath. heard two good sermons, from John 8-12.  received a letter from home to night & a paper wh. will come
Completed

July 5, Enjoyed much last night in reading the views of George Beecher as represented in his memoir on the character of unclear & joys of heaven.  My service never seems so lovely and heaven never so attractive.  Praise to God for these views.  
July 10 - received a good long letter from father, mother & brothers H.  H. has been home for some weeks sick - has now gone back & how full of gratitude sh'd I be that my friends are so well.  Mother says E. Ireland is not expected to live.  Hope she will be led to the Savior before it is to late.  How many warnings do I know to be ready - may I heed them all.  How uncertain.  How fleeting is life that if we are prepared no matter how soon we go home to Christ in heaven.
July 14 - mailed a letter home
July 16 - Had a pleasant ride on horses set about two miles to a Mr. Collins' - one of the trustees of school here himself and wife seemed very cordial.  Came home and as I looked at the beautiful moon and thought my N.E home far away and parents & brothers. 
July 17 - Visited this afternoon (Saturday) at Mr. Gross' with Mrs. Knapp.  carried melodian - very pleasant time.  Mrs. C come with me in the boat from Mackanaw? to Chicago.
July 24 - kept school 1/2 day cold all forenoon & hot all the afternoon & obliged to be in bed. Felt bad enough - was as Mr. Clay Olney's bus went to Mr. Knapp's at night.
25 Sab.  Spent at home on the best most of the time.  Thought much of God, of the eternal world.  My dear dear parents and brothers - what would they think did they know the state of my health now - but hope to be better soon.
July 28 - School to day  for the first time since Sat. and am so week and dizzy that I can just support myself.  Mr. & Mrs. Knapp have been very kind indeed I have had no appetite at all.  Cannot yet ? little things here, wh. are so grateful to the sick.
29 - rather stronger I think today and little more appetite .  Been thinking a good deal of Poor E. Ireland - Oh that she may be prepared for death.
Aug 1, Sabb,  attended meeting in the forenoon.  Heard that Miss Roberts is very near me - within about six miles - think she will come to meeting some Sabbath so that we may see each other.  Troubled with wondering thoughts Oh that I may keep the Sabbath holy.  There is a great amount of Sabbath sneaking here wish I could do something to prevent it and perhaps God will open a way.
Completed

Aug 6.  Have had now 26 different scholars.  How great my responsibility.  May God help me to do my duty.  Should be glad if I could hear from home often but I must submit.
Aug 7.  was made vary happy by a letter from home last evening. I do feel thankful that my dear parents and brothers are presently in health.  Praise God now in my letter - god's ways are mysterious.  E. Ireland is dead others I expected to hear and Mrs. Bavinhour? is gone to her home - two persons whom I should least have selected when I left home. May God sanctify these Providences to me and to all especially the young. 
Aug 8.  Attended meeting saw Miss Roberts. She stopped between meetings at Elder Knapps We were very happy to meet.  She says she is happy though there is no society there which she can enjoy  She does not know of a professor of religion in the immediate neighborhood - has 26 scholars on an average.  Hope we shall see each other often.
Aug 12. Do not feel at all able to go to school to day.  I hope it will be God's wish to grant me my health and strength for my labors, but not my will but thine be done.
Aug 14 Saturday, no school  finished my letter home.  Do not feel very well.  A Miss French got Mr. Parks from Lockport  come here Parks, Goody and I had to play as usual.  Mrs. G is one of the best of women.  I love her very much.  She does every thing for me and seems to feel as anxious as a mother.  Oh how thankful I ought to be for such friends.  They are from God's hand.
Aug 15 Sabbath.  I stayed at home with Mrs Goody today  do not love to stay at home when it is possible to go but I should get very tired, I am so weak and she advised am to say and try to get rest.  I have read in the Bible and in the Young Christian and have prayed God to bless me my parents and all my friends both here & far away - Hope the preaching at the chh I so love to attend; hence and every where will be attended with succes. abundant.  O my Father prepare me for the duties of this week many and great as they are - help me to trust alone in thee then shall I be safe.
Completed

myself I can do nothing.  I feel it very sensibly.
June 27.  Sabbath I feel more as if I was quite out at the West than I have before; Started for meeting {in the sch.house 2 miles distant this morning} with others in such a vehicle as we could unclear insertion lumber waggon - with 3 seats and two horses.  The school house was full and at noon a Sabbath school was organized -They have had none before quite a large school for the beginning.  I have had thrown upon me the responsible charge of a Bible class now numbering 10 - young ladies.  I was requested to take it and declined and supposed nothing more would be said but then it was announced to the class aloud that I would be teacher and I concluded to make no farther excuses but do as well as I could. unclear for help in him without whom I can do nothing.  This after noon at four o'clock went to meeting at my school house.  Mr. Knapp preaches in the sch. h. in one part of the little unclear in the forenoon and in the other part in the afternoon. He is quite as good a preacher as I expected.  Can't think much of dear parent and brothers today.  It makes my lip quiver and the tears start if I do.  How happy I should have been at home with them this summer, but I am in the path of duty, all is well.  Perhaps there are happy summers in store for me yet with them.  So I'll hope on.
Jun 29.  Have now 17 scholars see that troubles me is governing. O unclear I do not unclear line he is so full of all mischief;  The verse in Daily Good this morning is cheering - "Thou art my hiding place  - though shalt preserve me from trouble". "how are thy servants blessed by the Lord - his love is their defence. Eternal Wisd. is their guide, their help, Omnipotence, Oh may eternal wisdom guide me through.  I am so sinful and unworthy.  Him alone is my hope.
July 1.  Now 18 pupils - O that I may do my duty to them.  Paul may plant and Apollos water but God must give the increase." I think much of parents & brothers - mother sitting all alone.  
July 4th Sabbath - Went this forenoon to the school house to meeting  Mr. Knapp gone to St. Charles. So we had no preaching, but quite an intensely prayer meeting and Sabbath school.  Oh that I thought less of this world and more of God's glory, I think I desire to do good and to be useful to those among whom I am placed  am afraid my motives are wrong.  Search me and know my heart and lead into the right way   O my savior.  Oh may my dear parents & brothers have God's blessing abundantly  He knows their wants
Completed

June 19  Still lingering in Chicago.  feeling haste to get to my home.  hope the Ornes will speedily make arrangements for us to leave.  In the evening went to convention heard Reverend speak for the Tract cause.  Mr. Kent of Galena spoke. He was formerly a tract distribution.  Mr Montgomery spoke & Mr Peabody who  displays a German Tract wh he found in a [[?ristine}} family, more than 300 years old, by Luther, I believe.  
June 20 1847 Sabb.  The morning is glorious.  it seems as if all nature keeps Gods holy day  So calm and still is all around.  And yet man keeps it & not man breaks Gods Sabbath. This forenoon listened to a sermon from Rev. 2. 4.  by Mr. Montgomery  {This is my finest Sabbath in Illinois} One remark was that I be part? of the hr. has its meridian but it has no setting sun.  Therefore if you  know that a Christian has left his first love, you so not prove as some suppose that it is the natural course of things or that God expects it but you know that man is a wretched, unfaithful, short sighted being.  After noon.  Mr Mervin or Merwin from Isiah 9 - 6 "His name shall be called wonderful.  Have enjoyed the day much and hope I have gained some things in the chr counsel.  God be praised for all & that I was less worldly.  this is one of my transgressins?
June 21  This evening reached safely my western home at Yankee settlement.  Left Chicago in the stage about half past eight.  reached Mr. Knapp's residence about eight in the evening.  Kindly received.  Have'nt felt such a sensation of lonliness since I left home as I did when Miss Weller left me at the tavern at Lockport to arrive by private conveyance here while she went on to Wilmington.  I was left alone, my companions all gone, I was a stranger in a strange land emphatically, so totally unknown to all about me When I reached home and found myself kindly received, it took somewhat from the sadness of my feelings
June 22.  Mr. Knapp took me to day to visit a school about two miles form here in a nother part of the settlement taught by Miss. Cook.  She has about 50 scholars and is a superb teacher. 
June 23 School began with ten scholars.  It does not seem possible that I am at the west teaching.  That I have begun my two years task - and yet perhaps not hard years for they may become tired of my company and dissatisfied with me in some way and then I must take my departure
June 24  15 scholars to day June 25 16 today Oh! may my Savior assist me to do my duty and guide me in every step for unclear
Completed

20 leaf -
June 7 - Monday morn. About 91/2 o'c we left Mr. Pardue where we had a prayer meeting in two carriages for Rochester to which places our expenses were paid by Palmyra friends.  and $6,19 over plus. Mr. Newton the innkeeper went with us - inquiring for Mr. Allen an elder in the Presbyterian cch. in R. He knew the conductor of the cars to Buffalo and procured us a passage at half price $1,25.  Then as we had 6,50 surplus of what was given to pay our expenses to Rochester, so it cost us 69 cents each to unclear reached Buffalo about nine in the evening -  went to the American Hotel sent for Rev. Mr. Hopkins who com - met us. very cordially.  Private families received us.  Miss Bishop and I went to Mr. Ramsey's - very pleasant family.  Two sons and a daughter we saw and a cousin, Dana Ramsey   
Putnam Direct Letter
June 8.  About eight o'clock left for Niagara Falls in the charge of Mr. Hopkins - brother of the minister.  There was with us Mr. Osgood a returned missionary from India going to visit the falls - beside these two gentlemen, we had after we reached the Falls, to accompany us on our visit there, Mr Callahan - minister of the place and his brother a merchant there.  We went immediately to see the falls - went to an Indian curiosity shop on the way on Bath, Island - crossed on bridges to Goat Island and from the point called Hays Back first - viewed Niagara Falls in all the  sublimity and grandeur.  Thee, O Niagara, I attempt not to describe for language falls far short of feeling? in the task; thou art one of God's most noble wonders, awe struck I gaze on thee in silence for to speak would seem like sacrilege when listening to the voice & nature in Niagara thunder.  We viewed the falls from Luna Island and from prospect tower also descended a cylinder walked along under the north precipice to the cave of the winds - dined at the "Eagle".  After dinner with five carriages and 6 spur of horses we visited the Mineral Spring - drank the water - visited the Whirlpool wh. almost equaled the falls - on board the Maid of the Mist we sailed directly under the falls spray covering us like rain.  On the boat we had a most merry trip.  Went out in the evening.  The absence of the moon deducted somewhat form the glory of the view.
June 9.  visited the Pagoda and Chimera Obscura about quarter before five had a most splendid
Completed

view of the falls and surrounding scenery.  This is by some believed to be the best Chi. ob.* in the world, they did not see it in its perfection because it was too early.  Returned to Buffalo in the six oclock train.  
June 10.  Left B. in the steam boat Hendrik Hudson for Chicago with 16 other.  Miss Perry and the Misses unclear remained behind for sickness. The latter to avoid Sabbath traveling, I think it greatly to be lamented that this sabbath traveling has been so forced upon us - do hope one may never be placed in like circumstances again.  Sea sick nearly all day.  
June 11.  This morning three of our company left at Cleveland.  Miss Case, Bishop & Swain.  Terrible sea sickness to day. Lake very rough unclear unclear Got into - Detroit - river smooth water - feel better.  Three more left at Detroit to N..?.
June 12.  We are in Lake Huron.  Fine day - quite calm unclear At Port Sarnia  several of us went on the Grande Shore into one of the British stores.
13 Sabbath. Lake Michigan.  Had a season of Prayer with reading scriptures and singing this morning. O may the time come soon when gods day shall be regarded and man obey God's law.  It does not seem like the Sabbath here.
14th Had quite a severe gale last night = did not feel much fear  Prayed to him who overrules the storm to keep us all and he has kept us.  O how full of gratitude should we all be.  The wind blew - the waves dashed - the rain poured - and we are safe - Our God has preserved us - let us praise his holy name.
15. Last night arrived safely at Chicago Ill.  Went to the Sherman House and met there one of the Committee Mr Wright - This morn have seen all of them except two or three.  They have assigned places for five of our No.  I am to go to Hadley about 30 miles from this place - As the time for action approaches I sometimes feel my courage fail, but I must trust all to God - he directs all things right and I feel that he will send me to the very station where I ought to go and make useful there.
16.  Attended a meeting in the afternoon and evening of the Synod wh meets here this week.
17  Mailed a letter home
18 Visited one of the public schools in Chicago - one of the finest schools I ever knew - government perfect.  In afternoon & evening attended meeting of convention - Mr. Greene Secretary of Board there.
Completed

Nov. 25 Thanksgiving no meeting. Went to Wedding {Lorfair? Knapp's} in evening  enjoyed very well thought of home and dear friends there.
Dec - Letter from home father mother and brothers all wrote a portion. It was very very welcome. all are well.  I feel grateful to God that he has preserved my dear friends in health and happiness.
Dec 19 - Sabbath  - come to Elder Knapp last eve to spend a Sabbath and go to cch in Lockport.  Oh that it may not be a misspent Sabbath - my heart is cold & I have Ch: for grace to do soften it. __ met a unclear.  Dr. Merrit who was from Epsom and knew my parents there  urged me very much to go and see her I told him I would try.
Dec 25 - Christmas - went to Mr Hopkin's with Mr Clarey  Came home in the evening and found a box I had been expecting from home had arrived.  I was very happy indeed - it was full of tokens of love and kindness  I felt grateful that it came safely - God is good - His mercies are new every morning and fresh every evening.  O that I loved him more.
Dec 26. Sab.  The last Sabbath in the year. Oh how far am I from what I should be   let me seriously in Thine into my spiritual state. am I nearer heaven than when the year commenced!  I hope I do feel an increasingly intense in heavenly realities - Two dear friends, my own dear grandmother's - links in the chain that bound me to earth and now among the ransomed hosts above - and others whom I loved have during the past year found a home with the dead, and I know not who next may go - many doubtless will be deprived of dear friends by the grip of death ere the last Sabbath of another year comes round.
Completed

"How strangely death steps in to crush, the [ponders?] & punish hopes we cherish"
Jan 2, 1848- Tis the first Sabbath in the New Year.  This evening I have attended a prayer meeting at the school house very interesting -hope it will have a good influence.  No preaching to day-- spent my time at home in reading and singing-- had not opportunity to go any where to chh.  O may God enable me to spend this year far better and more to his glory than any former year of my life.  I leave some doubts and fears, but may I be assisted to go to the right source for relief-  I commit my self I friends to the care of my God for this year now commenced.  I earnestly desire if it is his will that we may all see it close in health and happiness but "not my will but thine be done".  Glory we all be useful while we are spared and spend our lives in God's good work.
Jan. 9. Sabbath. Elder Knopp preached at eleven- very few out  things look indeed very discouraging in a religious point of view- O that I felt more of a spirit of ardent prayer to God for my pupils and others who are careless.  Without God's blessing nothing can be done, and he has promised to hear the prayer of faith, I need more faith more love more devotedness to the cause of my savior.
Sab. Jan 16. Sabbath.  Such an interesting meeting- my heart condemns me daily because I do no more for God- but I do wish to do good and may my God help me to accomplish much.  I feel more than ever anxious for my dear pupils- may God make me the instrument of much good to them-
Sab. Jan. 30. Oh! may God help me to spend this day for thy glory-- may I this day remember that it is thine holy day- Gods day  does not have that sacredness which it once seemed to have-  The influence of being in this country in that respect is bad- but I do hope I shall yet be enabled to attach to it the same sacredness I once did, even here.
Completed

May 3rd, 1847 Left home with my parents for Boston on my unclear to Albany to join the company of Western teachers.  Passed that night  unclear unclear after calling at D C Rice? and left them Tuesday afternoon on  unclear passed  She may unclear at Lucile Mason's in Boston.  Left at 8 o'c. in the morning & girls here went on to Western & for Friday  After a ride of ten horses in unclear ferrys and crossing the Hudson for Greenbush in a ferry boat that launched unclear about 6 1/2 oc with 8 others of unclear enterprise.  Saw Miss unclear at Mrs. Delivan house and very, very busy day place about eight o'clock unclear  at the First Academy at unclear.
May 7. Mr A Whiss  unclear at 21/2 oc might back and wrote to my dear parents
May. 8.  Mailed my letter to parents from my first composition dissatisfied enough with it but did as he unclear and unclear appease out not to compromise
May 9  Sabbath My father in PM  unclear
Completed

mother in another, brothers separated and little self far from them all - in the city of Albany - could realize it at all.  But God is present every where and may his presence and blessing be with us scattered as we are.  Attended the Baptist- chh, in the forenoon with the family  Sermon from Rom 3::31.  In the afternoon attended a Presbyterian chh.  text in Joshua 13-7. subj: Missions. 10 million expended for cigars yearly - and 3 millions for the [conversin?] of the soul. Oh the stupidity . the blindness of some.  Lord, help me to know my duty and perform it truly in God  Interesting program meeting at 6 1/2 oc attended image wants all the young ladies.
May 11. Had a season of prayer with Mrs. B. and her sister. How thankful sh'd I be that I am with
Completed

those whom I think are interested for me and for the enterprise in wh, I expect to engage.  Miss. Beecher says- order punctuality & neatness are the prominent virtues we shall be called to exercise in our Western homes.
May 12. Visited the  Normal school- supported by the State at the expense of ten thousand dollars annually.  Exercises exceedingly interesting- heard classes in reading & grammar How thankful ought I to be for my privileges- first - to God then to my parents and those at the head of this Western Enterprise.
May 13th.  Received a letter fr. Father write on his return to our "deserted cottage" after attending uncle's A's installation at Epsom. Contains good advice, as ever.  Visited Normal School again . heard lessons in Grammar & geography. Called at Mr. James. He is a kind good man- takes a quiet interest in the young ladies.
Completed

walked home with one of our No. Miss. Bishop  She said she had the most violent opposition at the moment she started. and from parents and family friends.  She said the reason was the trial was too great- they wanted her at home and did no feel that they could consent to her leaving them.  May God make her path of duty plain. and may she walk therein- 
May 14, Visited the Gallery of fine arts- Ticket of admittance twice, from Rev William James. Some of the pictures are very beautiful indeed and all are finely executed. In the afternoon Mr. Payer- (at the head of the Normal School) lectured on method of teaching reading to young pupils-  He was exceedingly interesting and his instructions are highly valuable. 
15th.  In the afternoon a lecture from Mr. Paye. a continuation of his former duty: dwelt  principaly  on teaching reading to older pupils.
16. Sab.  The day is calm and beautiful. Welcome day of holy rest- day of triumph over death and the grave.  Oh that I appreciate this blessedness as I sh'd.  Many begin this day with prayer- with ardent desires that God may be glorified and sinners loved, while others hail its coming as a day of [sensual?]
Completed

gratification, in which they seek not, and care not for aught love worldly pleasure.  Oh that I felt is sacredness more, and that my wondering thoughts were more fixed on heavenly things.  I must be much in proper that God, for Christ's sake, would help.   Seminar in the forenoon.
Text & Eph. 1::1-8. afternoon 1st Peter 1::24. For all flesh is as grass &c. A very solemn  and impressive Sermon.  How little do I realize my frailty -I live on as though I believe not and know not that I must die. And yet the hour of dissolution must come and I know not how soon.  I live far very  far from what I ought an yet however much I resolve to do different, I live on at the same poor dying rate.  I trust too much in myself.  I do not strive to enter in at the straight gates as I should do.  Love both me to know mine end, and the meadow of my days what it is; that I may know how frail I am.  To day is the last day in wh. I shall be able to say I am seventeen.  Tomorrow will be my 18th birthday.  Should I live to behold its dawn, may I spend it, as all my days sh'd be spent,"in serving God' and blessing mankind".
May 17, The morning is exceeding my lovely, I could not not desire a more pleasant morn, to usher in my 19th year, It is very hard
Completed

work to believe that I am so old I certainly never felt young- I have many things for wh. to praise God as I review  the past year, and many things to ??net as I examine any improvement as Gods minions- Oh! for a heart to feel - to adore - to love: how little do I appreciate my blessings. I know not where my God will place me this new year - I know not what trials and perplexities I am to meet and I know not how much good God may permit me to do - but if I have his presence and blessing a disposition and ability to labor new health and of my own parents and friends are blessed thus spiritually and temporally - what need I ask more?  
May 18.  Today received a present from Miss. B of two bound volumes  and a phamphlet written by herself- very valuable.  Received a letter from mother dated at Douglass. Went with Mrs. Wysman Miss, Egeney and Miss Bush to Troy to meet some ladies
Completed

interested in our cause - had a delightful ride and a delightful interview with the ladies at the house of a Mrs. Gardner.  Feel quite happy to night.  Last night I felt quite low spirited - received a letter from Mother to day - from Douglass
19.  Present of a grammer by the author G. B. Peirce - called on a Mrs. White who was the daughter of Elisha Putnam - she wishes to find out our connexion - Her father has 
sev. broth 0 in N. Y.?   John - in Chesterton Vt.
20. Visited Gallery of Fine Arts to day.  Some most exquisite painting - a few by a Roman painter - Signore Narducci.   Hardly dare to 'look ahead" - sometimes feel that I have undertaken more than I shall accomplish.  The work grows longer & larger as I view it, but there is help in one.
May 23 Sunday.  Baptist meeting in the forenoon.  Text Psalms 96-6. Presbyterian in P.M.  1st. Tim 1-11.  Oh that my stony heart bight be softened by divine grace - that I might feel as well as know the infinite benevolence of God.  the love of Ch. and my need of the influence of the Holy Spirit.
Completed

Had a delightful prayer meeting this eve with the young ladies.  Oh let not these privileges be misimproved.  What abundent cause have I for deep gratitude to my maker. In Christians all my hope - in him is strength Without his assistance all is in vain.  
24, Wrote home.  25. Mailed a letter home.  Visited the capital - went to the top. 26 - Had dress cut.  May 30. Sab. Heard Dr. Nott preach two most excellent sermons from Eph.5.-14.  Oh! may what I have heard today be as seed on good ground wh. shall spring up and bear fruit - to God's glory.  The manners of Dr N. is somewhat peculier - very few gestures, but he speaks with much feeling and solemnity & correctness.  His appearance is venerable, and his style of writing very fine.  I believe his age is about     We have this evening enjoyed a refreshing season of prayer together.  CS: for more
Completed
love to Christ & more confidence in God and more of the Holy spirits reviving presence.  my heart is cold and hard.
Completed

June 20, 1848 today arrived in Chicago on my way to my own New England.  May God's blessing rest upon the kind friends I leave & may he reward them for their great kindness 
21 - To day received a line from Dea. Parker who is to accompany me home.  he will meet me perhaps to
Completed

night probably not till next Monday.  I feel now that I am really started quite anxious to go on immediately, but shall spend most of my time with Miss Roberts.  Think much of parents - Perhaps they are thinking of me too -
words on left side crossed out
Completed

21 - About six o'clock this afternoon Dea. P. to my great joy appeared.  About nine oclock we left for St. Joseph's in the Saml Ward.  
22  arrived at St. Jos about 3 1/2 oc. in the morning.  Took the stage - passed through Berrin, Niles, where we dined - then through Bertrand to South Bend.  Arrived at Plymouth about nine in the evening 
23 Rochester

\
Completed

at three in the morning and Logansport about ten.  Dined there and started for Delphi where we arrived about half past seven in the evening - and spent the night.
24 To night about 6 oc. we reached Crawfordsville & found the friends very glad to see us. Passed through La Fayette & ____ on the way.
Completed

25 Sabbath.  Heard Mr. Johnston preach in the forenoon & evening and Mr. White The president of the college in the afternoon at three.  There are over 100 students connected with the institution. Saw them all seated together in the body of the house.  
26  Walked about the College building wh. is situated in a most
Completed

beautiful grove.  Went to The Museum and Library.  Started between seven and eight to return to Logansport.  Spent the night - again at Delphi.
27 Reached Logansport about noon - dined here.  There is a young lady here who is a blind.  I never felt so forcibly the blessing of sight.
Completed

Oh, may I be truly thankful to the giver of every good gift - for this and every blessing - Expect to go out in a packet for Toledo at six to night. 
28 Came on board the packet.  Ohio - Capt Smith.  Found on board a second cousin Miss Susan Matthews from Putnam Ohio and Miss Catherine Levens a daugther of Capt Warner.
Completed

This unclear make my way very pleasant Oh how good is God, let not my soul forget his benefits.
29 Expect to reach Toledo to night.  Met Mr. Carnaham a clergyman from Crawfordville.  I have had the care of a blind girl from Logansport to Fort Wayne who had been to Columbus at the Institution for the Blind and was returning home from a similar instruction at Indianapolis.  Her name was ______
Completed

Clarissa Marquart - she is a member of the Methodist Church and a very good girl.
30 Here I am at Thayer's Exchange in the city of Toledo - Expect to leave at eight in the Indiana for Buffalo.  may God watch over protect me and help me to feel safe in his hands, Miss Mathews & Levens go with me as far as Sandusky.
Completed

Jan 9.1851 Father preached - Forenoon 2 Cor. 4.11.  1. Consider the prominent graces which adorn the Savior's character.  1. Humility. 2. Patience 3. Devotedness 4. Decision and Forgiveness. 5. Prayerfulness.  2. The importance of imitating these.
Afternoon - Galatians. 4.18 -
1.The nature of true zeal. 1. It springs from knowledge.  2. It is induced by good motives of heart  3. It is directed in the right way to the accomplishment of the best ends
2. It is duty of every one to posses true zeal for God.  Every Christian should be active in laboring for God.  Soon the night will come and no more opportunity be offered to 
cooperate with God in the glorious work of the world's conversion.
Jan 16 - (Father)
Forenoon - Psalms 119-129 - "Thy testimonies are wonderful."  The bible is a wonderful book, not only because of its Author but because of the contents.  The doctrines it reveals - the precepts it (contains) enforces - The history it discloses - all are wondrous - It tells us of the character of God. "Glorious in holiness fearful in praises, doing wonders" It also tells us the character of man.  naturally sinful, totally depraved - wholly opposed to all that is good and holy. 
Many efforts have been made to destroy the Bible - to banish it entirely from the world, but it has stood, while empires and kingdoms have fallen.  Those nations which obeyed its precepts have been blessed and prospered while those who neglected it and affected to despise its precepts have felt God's just displeasure and in some instances been entirely overthrown.  It is to the Bible that his people owe their prosperousness and happy state.  Shall we not then scatter to the world, those C?o..s? wh. shall for this healing of the nations - let us do with our unclear

Afternoon- John 5-1::9.
In the introduction reference to the twice yearly feasts of the Jews- The one reference to was probably the Pasover "A pool"- a bathing place or spring possibly medicinal qualities to which at certain seasons great multitudes resorted to be healed of diseases-  We learn important lessons from this narration-  1. We see the helpless state of the sinner  2. That ample provisions is made for their salvation-  3. The willingness of Christ to save.  4. We are entirely dependent on God for aid-  5. It is our duty to avail ourselves of the means by grace so far as in our power, The healing stream would have been useless, had not the impotent resorted within and availed themselves of its virtues.  6. If we press forward in the discharge of every duty and obey the command of the Savior, we shall find abundant aid will be bestowed-  God himself will be our helper-

The others came in the boat with the fishes.  After their simple
Completed

repast "Jesus said to Simon Peter "Simon Son of Jonas, Lovest thou me more than these . After receiving his reply "Yes, Lord, thou knowest that I love thee", Jesus again put the question, and received a like reply- You saith unto him the third time "Simon, Son of Jonas, lovest thou me "? "Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time Lovest thou me? And he said unto him, Lord, thou knowest all things, thou knowest that I love thee".
The question thus addressed by our Lord to his disciples, was full of solemn meaning, and is no less so at the present time.  In order fully and clearly to understand it's import, we may consider-
1. The nature of true love to our Savior.

   1. It is the love of [complacency?].  Thee should love Christ for what he is in himself- Because we see and feel that he is indeed pure and good "glorious in holiness", infinitely worth, our highest adoration, and our truest, purest, love-
   2. It is disinterested. 
   3. It is supreme- It fills all our being. 
   4. It is active. It will lead us to devote our whole life to this service, who alone is worthy, our supreme affection- cheerfully we shall labor for Him, if we truly love Him.

2. Consider the importance of exercising this love, 

    1. It is the foundation of all moral excellence, All else is as "sounding brass on a tinkling symbol" 
    2. It makes us like God.
    3. It is the only thing that can fill us for the endless bliss of Heaven.
 How infinitely important then that we possess this love- it should actuate every act of our life, and animate every hope.  Without it we perish eternally.  We learn, hence, the duty of rigid self examination-

Forenoon - John 21.15 & 16.
Introductions - mentioned the circumstances under which Christ and his disciples had met - The addresses to Peter the inquiry, solemnly and earnestly - "Lovest thou me" and after receiving his reply gives him a charge - "Feed my lambs" and "my sheep"- as much as to say - If thou lovest me labor for me - do my will minister to my followers.  This Peter obeyed to the end of life.  The apostles and many other of the early Christians, literally, did what they could - they forsook houses and lands and kindred.  all that was dear to them.  They were cast out despised and driven from city to city - exposed to dangers, hardships and trials of every description, till at last they laid down their lives even for Christ's sake.  And gladly they submitted to these things, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer for Christ.  If then we truly love Christ it will lead to action - to ardent self denying effort to save souls.  We are Christians just so far as we are like Christ.  He loved to do the will of his father.  His life was spent in laboring for souls.  It is there in vain to suppose ourselves Christians and never put forth one effort for the salvation of our fellow beings. If we would do good we must 1. The Pharisees were a sect among the Jews who were distinguished for their hypocritical worship - They enlarged the border of the garments made broad, their phylacteries prayed. standing in the corner of the streets, to be seen of men - loved the chief seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the markets, and to be called of men

June 8, 1857.  Rev. Mr. Holcomb from N. York  Agent for the "American & Foreign Christian Union".  Preached through the day from the first verse of the sixth chapter of Galatians.  "Brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, ye which are spiritual restore" &c  The Romish and Greek churches represent the 'Brother overtaken in a fault".  It is the duty of "those which are spiritual" or whom God had saved from error to restore as far as in their power  God helping them these fallen churches. They were once the true church, to whom the apostles and Christ himself preached.  At one time it seemed as if the Romish power would annihilate true Christianity - reference to the thirty years war and the victorious army of the Swedish Prince Gustavas Adolphus  Since this, until very recently the feeling has seemed to exist that to convert Romanists would be a hopeless undertaking.  But it is found they may be affected by the truth.  Their affectus must be won, their confidence secured, and they will listen - (reference to the labors of Dr. Calla on the island of Madere among the Portuguese now on the island of Malta, - still among Catholics) - also reference to the state of things in Italy at Rome French bayonets restored the Pope, and they alone retain him in his position.  1500 Italians in N. York - not one is at heart a Romanist.  The death blow has been given to Popery at Rome, and its foundations tremble through the world.  A chapel - called the American Protestant Chapel is located at Rome.  Mr. Cass the chaplain. Ministers of every denomination there proclaim the gospel.  It is a Protestant chapel non-denominational.
Completed

July 13 - Mr Merrill from  Penbroke.  Amos - 4.11. Ye were as a firebrand plucked out of the burning.  This language is a figurative representation of the Christian State - Every christian might before conversion have been likened to a firebrand, which while it destroys, is itself destroyed.  Sin is the consuming fire. The firebrand, when placed in favorable circumstances may produce a vast conflagration and destroy a large amount of property.  It may be placed in a situation in which is will only consume itself.  So the sinner, one sinner may beside being himself destroyed effects the ever-lasting ruin of a third - - The christian is a firebrand plucked from the burning.  The fire of sin was consuming him but the hand of God was stretched
Completed

out and he was plucked from the burning - saved forever - Thanks be to a merciful God!  The christian is under everlasting obligation to heaven for his rescue - 'A great weight of responsibility - is resting upon him.  Can he who has himself been plucked from the burning be indifferent while those about him, perhaps in his own family circle, bone of his bone and flesh of his flesh, are still under the power of sin?  If God has mercifully rescued us from this consuming fire how zealous should we be in endeavoring to save others from the save destruction which threatened us!  The blood of Jesus alone is effectual in quenching the fires of sin.    Afternoon.  Luke 23-35 - Father.  Forgive them, for they  know not what they do.  (First - a brief statement of the circumstances in which these words were uttered.  - The Savior was already nailed to the cross - the cruel irons were driven into his hands and feet and the spear had pierced his side - with his bloody persecutors all about him rejoicing in the belief that their wicked designs were nearly accomplished  Jesus spoke in the language of the text "father forgive them for they know not what they do'!
Completed

They know not what they did.  They saw not the depth of their crime and its enormous wickedness.  No sinner sees his guilt in its true light; does not feel the depth of his sin - nor does he feel how terrible is the wrath of God which rests upon him, as long as he loves sin.  We can see something of the wickedness of sin when we look at the effects of it in the world.  It brings want and woe, sickness, poverty; and pain and at last it takes even life away.  Sinners know not what they do when they delay repentance. The burden of crimes is constantly accumulating, and God's displeasure increasing.  He knows not the guilt of rejecting salvation purchased with the blood of Gods eternal son; else would he fly without delay to the only refuge.

There are literally two opposite declarations; the one representing God to be incapable of repenting; the other that he actually does repent.  So also in 1. Sam. 15, "The strength of Israel will not lie nor repent; for he is not a man that he should repent."  And Gen. 6 It repent
Completed

repented the Lord that he had made man upon the earth.  Object of the discourse to reconcile these apparent opposing declarations of God's word.  1.  Consider what is implied in repentance.  1. A change of purpose. 2 A change of heart. 3 A change of unclear conduct, as a fruit.  2. Consider in what sense God does not repent.  He does not change his purpose. He does not change his heart. 3.  In what sense does he repent? The changes in relation to his external actions or, the dealings of his Providence. - He only seems to man to repent   It is in this sense only that the term can be applied.  We find illustrations of God's change of providence or treatment of man in the case of the antediluvians , Pharaoh, the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah, and the rebellious Israelites.  This subject shows 1. The wisdom of trusting and obeying God.  He is the same yesterday, today and forever.  2. It shows the folly of forgetfulness of God, and disobedience to his commands.

Oct.12 Psalm 219:139. "My zeal hath consumed me, because mine enemies have forgotten thy words." Zeal for God and for his glory.  The real disciple of Jesus is full of grief when beholding the enemies of God forgetful of his commands and despising reproof. rushing headlong down to death.  Design of the discourse to show why good men thus grieve at the transgressions of the wicked.  They love this law of God and earnestly desire to see all about them respecting and obeying it. They know too, that to disregard the law of God, will prevent happiness here  They love their fellow men, and grieve to see them perusing a course which is certain misery for this world.  More than this they know that a life of sin will lead inevitably to ruin in a coming world.  The love of souls induces them to plead with the ungodly to receive Christ.
Do we grieve as did pious David over the carelessness and the danger of the unpenitent about us? Why do we not pray more; cry mightily unto God to save these "Who fervent, effectual prayer of the righteous man availeth much?

Protecting from plague , and the Christian religion is protected by established law, so that there is no persecution.  There was a time when those who acknowleged Christ must do it with the loss of all things literally.  The goods of a merchant were thrown into the street, and himself not permitted to lay his finger on a single article which the rabble plundered all . They were turned out of their own houses into the street and not even permitted to remain there, but cast into prisons and loathsome dungeons affording no place to sit in, no place to stand up in, or to lie down in; where they must every moment be suffering, and tortured with pain.  Consider man's wants.
1. Saving knowledge.  Man has knowledge by which he can make the rivers his road and the ocean his highway.  We can measure the distance to the sum and the stars, and make the lightening of heaven do his bidding he can weigh the hills in scales and the mountains in a balance. He has powers which fit him to be a companion of angels, and yet he needs that knowledge which will save the soul.  All else is vain.
2. Man needs justifying righteousness, No man can obtain this by his own merits,
3. He needs the aids of the Holy Spirit
4. He needs an Almighty Friend to protect him against the evils who encompass him. 
5 Man wants a home in heaven. To know how dear is an earthly home and how we pity the homeless  wanderer.  No home in all the wide unfriendly world!  Well may we love our earthly home, but we need a home beyond the skies, when the turmoil of life shall be past.

 show what is implied in a saving acquaintance with God.
 Why should we now seek to become savingly acquainted with our Maker.
 # Show what is implied etc.
  1. We must have some conception of his infinite power.  In this he differs from the heathen deities, they are mere stumps on stones, powerless and lifeless. But who can resist.  Jehovah's might!  This people may say "The Lord is my strength and my shield; he is the saving strength of his anointed". 
  2. Some conception of his omnipresence  The gods of the heathens must remain where they are placed, but the Christian's God is everywhere. His presence pervades the memberless worlds that roll in their vast orbits through the regions of infinite space.
  3. We must know that he is holy.
  4. That he hates sin.  This very love of holiness teaches this.  He is just and he will punish the transgressor.
  5. We must love the character of God and approve of all his attributes and perfections.
  6. We must cordially acquiesce in his plans, and accept his terms of salvation.

Forenoon text in Psalms 11-4- "The Lord is in his Holy Temple- the Lord's throne is in heaven; his eyes behold, his eye lids try the children of men".  Consider some evidences by which we sinners try ourselves, to know whether indeed we are true disciples of Jesus
1.  The true Christian loved all in whom he sees the image of his divine master and loves them because they are like Jesus.  "We know", says the apostle "that we have passed from death unto life, because we love the brethren.  He that loveth not his brother abideth in death."
2. A feeling of good will towards all men, is requisites even towards seen enemies.  In this we have our Savior's example.  He died for sinners, for those even, who were his murderers.  It was love and good will to all which led him to give his life to save poor ruined man.
3. Delight in the character of God & in communion with him, is an evidence of Christian character.  We must love to go to God and tell him our need and our sorrow, and joys, as to a dearly loved friend.  
$. The Christian loves God's word.  It is his daily meditation.  He "longs for its precepts". They are his meat and drink, Says the Psalmist. "How sweet are thy words unto my taste! Yea, sweeter than honey to my mouth."

A Wish
O, place no useless form of Art
Above my head.
But when this mortal life departs,
Check the warm gushings of your hearts;
And when "the prayers are said,"
And I am sweetly laid to rest,
Where sin can never more malest,
Oh let my name forgotten lie,
Nor tell it to the passer by.
But plant a single tree as flora's,
To mark the spot;
There let some living emblem wave,
When I am not
A thing of art, will pass away
But nature lives e'er in decay.
'Twere better far to send the "Word"
To heatthen shore,
To point the sinner to his God,
And lead him to a rich reward,
When life is o'er,
Than have the loftiest sculptured pile,
Reveal my resting place the while.
Strangers might for a moment gaze,
Upon my name;
Then all unthinking pass along,
Just as they came:
But few, upon my grave will shed,
Affections tear when I am dead.
Then let me seek the world to bless,
Tis truly wise;
Who renders human suffering less,
Who aids the poor, in their distress, 
Beyond the skies,
Shall reap a rich and sure reward, 
For service rendered to his Lord.
The Silver and the gold, are this,
and only lent
To us, to be employed for him,
By whom they're sent.
To lead lost souls to Christ and Heaven,
To us the wealth of earth is given.
Completed

Little Things
Of what is life composed! Is it not  almost entirely, of little things. little acts; little every day duties.  Occasionally, indeed, something occurs which we may call s great event; but may we not usually trace the origin of this to some slight cause so slight we scarcely deemed it worthy note.  These little things they may be little in themselves, but they are all important At times, we are almost forced to believe there are no little things, so mighty is their influence.  So closely are they interwoven with the very thread of man's existence.  Who has not felt even in the heart's deepest successes, a small unkindness perchance a single thoughtless word! And who has not felt too, a thrill of gladness when greeted with kind words and deeds of love?  That casts a magic spell round home, and makes the humblest [roof?] that wh. hears that name like an enchanted spot!  What makes the heart to cling to home, and it's loved circle of tried, faithful friends? Those little offices of love. those little nameless duties which we every day perform for each other, most certainly, unite bind our hearts more closely together. [last three words crossed through and replaced  with following] in one so that nothing can break the golden cords that bind them.
Let us never omit a duty because it is a little one. Let us never be silent when we might utter a word of kindness.  It may send joy to some over burdened heart.  It may cause hope to spring up in some lonely and desolate bosom It may help some struggling, discouraged one in the path of trouble & virtue & right.
